fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.bodyText: • A news story – University marking to be reviewed over grade inflation fears, 11 September, page 14 – said that under the current system students' work is marked by two examiners from their university, then a third from another, giving rise to the criticism that these external examiners are unregulated and may be personal contacts of tutors. One such examiner has written to point out that marking is normally outside the role of the external person, whose job is rather to look at whether the process of assessment is sound and has operated fairly. • In a 10-of-the-best feature (Ruined castles, 11 August, page 14, G2) we situated Conwy Castle in Gwynedd when it is now in Conwy, and Framlingham Castle in Norfolk when it is – the Dukes of Norfolk notwithstanding – in Suffolk. • In a piece about Michael Shields, the British man pardoned this week after being jailed for attempted murder, we gave the name of the Bulgarian victim in the case as Michael Georgiev. His forename is Martin ('I knew I would never walk alone', 10 September, page 9). • Homophone corner: "The school is the village's most prominent building, with a bell tower that houses a carillon, and peels each quarter hour" (Bournville was built as a new Jerusalem, 11 September, page 19, G2). • Our Wilco gig review (Southern-fried Wilco still on the hunt for their own identity, 27 August, page 38) said that singer Jeff Tweedy was the band's "only constant" in its 15-year career. Bass guitarist John Stirrat has also been in Wilco from the start. reader@theguardian.com
